column1: When there exists an inherited or instinctive tendency to the performance of an action
column2: or an inherited taste for certain kinds of food
column3: some degree of habit in the individual is often or generally requisite. We find this in the paces of the horse
column4: and to a certain extent in the pointing of dogs; although some young dogs point excellently the first time they are taken out
column5: yet they often associate the proper inherited attitude with a wrong odor
column6: and even with eyesight. I have heard it asserted that if a calf be allowed to suck its mother only once
column7: it is much more difficult afterwards to rear it by hand. Caterpillars which have been fed on the leaves of one kind of tree
column8: have been known to perish from hunger rather than to eat the leaves of another tree
column9: although this afforded them their proper food
column10: under a state of nature; and so it is in many other cases.
